Federal Reserve Tone Decoder

Federal Reserve Tone Decoder: interpreting key Fed communications

As of 2025-12-13

Communications Interpretation Module

Fed Tone Decoder – Communications Interpretation Module.

Speaker: Chair Powell | Date: December 10, 2025 | Source: Chair Powell's Press Conference Transcript

  • Labour Market: ✗ — Labor market is "gradually cooling," "job gains have slowed," and "downside risks to employment appear to have risen." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ — Inflation "remains somewhat elevated," with goods inflation up due to tariffs, but services disinflation continuing. Tariff effects are expected to be a "one-time shift." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Policy Bias: Easing (+2) — Policy rate was lowered by ¼ percentage point, and purchases of shorter-term Treasury securities initiated to maintain ample reserves. Policy is now "within a broad range of estimates of its neutral value," "well positioned to wait and see." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Risk Asymmetry: ✓ — Risks to employment are tilted to the "downside" and have "risen." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ — Committee decision was "clearly very divided" with "strongly differing views" on future path; two official dissents and four soft dissents. [Source: press_monetary_policy]

TONE: DOVISH — Further rate cut and balance sheet purchases signal strong support for employment amid cooling labor market and two-sided risks, despite elevated inflation and notable committee divergence on future path.

Event: Rate Decision | Date: December 11, 2025

Policy Action: 25bps CUT

Context: This cut continued the easing cycle, positioning policy within a neutral range, informed by persistent downside risks to employment and continued elevated but expected-to-decline inflation. Initiated Treasury bill purchases to maintain ample reserves.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: December 10, 2025 | Source: FOMC Statement

  • Labour Market: ✗ — "Job gains have slowed this year, and the unemployment rate has edged up through September." "downside risks to employment rose in recent months." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Inflation Concern: ✗ — "Inflation has moved up since earlier in the year and remains somewhat elevated." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Policy Bias: Easing (+2) — "Decided to lower the target range for the federal funds rate by 1/4 percentage point to 3-1/2 to 3-3/4 percent." "Initiate purchases of shorter-term Treasury securities as needed." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Risk Asymmetry: ✓ — "Downside risks to employment rose in recent months." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ — Multiple dissents noted, including one for a larger cut and two for no change. [Source: press_monetary_policy]

TONE: DOVISH — Rate cut and initiation of Treasury purchases reflect increasing concern for employment risks, despite elevated inflation and internal dissent, signaling a clear shift towards easing.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: December 10, 2025 | Source: SEP

  • Labour Market: ✓ — Median unemployment rate projected at 4.5% for 2025, declining to 4.2% by 2028 (consistent with stable/low from prior SEP). [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ — Median PCE inflation projected at 2.9% for 2025, then falling to 2.4% (2026), 2.1% (2027), and 2.0% (2028). [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Policy Bias: Easing (+2) — Federal funds rate median projections show further cuts: 3.6% (2025), 3.4% (2026), 3.1% (2027), representing a continued downward shift from the September SEP. [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Risk Asymmetry: ✓ — FOMC Statement from same day noted "downside risks to employment rose in recent months." (Inferring from concurrent policy statement.) [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ — The accompanying press conference noted "strongly differing views" regarding the future path of rate cuts. [Source: press_monetary_policy]

TONE: DOVISH — Significant downward revision in the median projected federal funds rate path for 2025-2027, signaling an accommodative stance despite unemployment remaining low, and inflation expected to gradually decline.

Speaker: Federal Reserve System | Date: November 17, 2025 | Source: Beige Book (November 2025)

  • Labour Market: ✗ — "Employment declined slightly," "weaker labor demand," "layoff announcements," "hiring freezes, replacement-only hiring, and attrition." [Source: Federal_Reserve_Beige_Book_Summary.html]
  • Inflation Concern: ✗ — "Prices rose moderately," "Input cost pressures were widespread...reflecting tariff-induced increases." [Source: Federal_Reserve_Beige_Book_Summary.html]
  • Policy Bias: Data-dependent (0) — Reports on economic conditions, not policy direction.
  • Risk Asymmetry: ✓ — "Increased risk of slower activity," "downside risks to employment appear to have risen." [Source: Federal_Reserve_Beige_Book_Summary.html]
  • Internal Divergence: ✗ — Not applicable to Beige Book.

TONE: NEUTRAL — Labor market weakening and increasing economic distress among lower-income households suggest dovish pressure, but moderate price increases, particularly due to tariffs, offset a stronger dovish signal.

Event: Rate Decision | Date: October 30, 2025

Policy Action: 25bps CUT

Context: This cut continued the easing cycle initiated in September, responding to rising downside risks to employment and persistent but expected-to-ease inflation pressures. The Committee also announced an end to balance sheet runoff.

Speaker: Chair Powell | Date: October 29, 2025 | Source: Chair Powell's Press Conference Transcript

  • Labour Market: ✗ — Labor market is "gradually cooling," "job gains have slowed significantly," and "downside risks to employment appear to have risen." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Inflation Concern: 0 — Inflation "remains somewhat elevated," but "inflation away from tariffs is actually not so far from our 2 percent goal." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Policy Bias: Easing (+2) — Policy rate was lowered by ¼ percentage point, and the reduction of aggregate securities holdings will conclude on December 1. Moving towards a "more neutral policy stance." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Risk Asymmetry: ✓ — "Downside risks to employment having increased in recent months, the balance of risks has shifted." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ — "Strongly differing views" on future policy, with two members dissenting: one for a ½ point cut, one for no change. [Source: press_monetary_policy]

TONE: DOVISH — Policy rate cut and cessation of balance sheet runoff underscore a primary focus on mitigating rising employment risks and shifting towards a neutral stance, despite lingering inflation concerns and visible internal division.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: October 29, 2025 | Source: FOMC Minutes

  • Labour Market: ✗ — "Job gains had slowed this year," "unemployment rate had edged up but remained low." "Downside risks to employment had risen." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Inflation Concern: ✗ — "Inflation had moved up since earlier in the year and remained somewhat elevated." "Core inflation had remained elevated." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Policy Bias: Easing (+2) — "Many participants were in favor of lowering the target range." "Almost all participants noted... appropriate to conclude the reduction of its aggregate securities holdings on December 1." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Risk Asymmetry: 0 — "Upside risks to inflation remained elevated and that downside risks to employment were elevated and had increased since the first half of the year." Balanced approach stressed. [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ — "Several were against lowering the target range." "One participant preferred a 1/2 percentage point reduction." [Source: press_monetary_policy]

TONE: NEUTRAL — The Committee moved to cut rates and end QT due to rising employment risks and a softening labor market, balanced by elevated inflation and persistent upside risks. A stated commitment to further easing, alongside notable dissent, points to ongoing policy debate.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: October 29, 2025 | Source: FOMC Statement

  • Labour Market: ✗ — "Job gains have slowed this year, and the unemployment rate has edged up but remained low through August; more recent indicators are consistent with these developments." "downside risks to employment rose in recent months." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Inflation Concern: ✗ — "Inflation has moved up since earlier in the year and remains somewhat elevated." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Policy Bias: Easing (+2) — "Decided to lower the target range for the federal funds rate by 1/4 percentage point to 3-3/4 to 4 percent." "The Committee decided to conclude the reduction of its aggregate securities holdings on December 1." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Risk Asymmetry: ✓ — "Downside risks to employment rose in recent months." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ — "Voting against this action were Stephen I. Miran, who preferred to lower the target range...by 1/2 percentage point...and Jeffrey R. Schmid, who preferred no change." [Source: press_monetary_policy]

TONE: DOVISH — The rate cut and end of balance sheet runoff signal a proactive response to increased downside risks in employment, despite persistent elevated inflation and notable internal disagreement.

Speaker: Federal Reserve System | Date: October 06, 2025 | Source: Beige Book (October 2025)

  • Labour Market: ✗ — "Employment levels were largely stable," but "demand for labor was generally muted" with "more employers reported lowering head counts through layoffs and attrition." [Source: Federal_Reserve_Beige_Book_Summary.html]
  • Inflation Concern: ✗ — "Prices rose further," "input costs increased at a faster pace due to higher import costs." "Tariff-induced input cost increases." [Source: Federal_Reserve_Beige_Book_Summary.html]
  • Policy Bias: Data-dependent (0) — Reports on economic conditions, not policy direction.
  • Risk Asymmetry: ✓ — "Elevated economic uncertainty," "downside risk to growth from a prolonged government shutdown." [Source: Federal_Reserve_Beige_Book_Summary.html]
  • Internal Divergence: ✗ — Not applicable to Beige Book.

TONE: NEUTRAL — Labor market shows signs of softening, and economic uncertainty is elevated with downside risks to growth, but inflation concerns remain due to rising input costs and expected further price pressures.

Event: Rate Decision | Date: September 18, 2025

Policy Action: 25bps CUT

Context: This marked the start of the easing cycle, prompted by a shift in the balance of risks towards employment downside and a re-evaluation of the neutral policy stance, despite inflation remaining elevated.

Speaker: Chair Powell | Date: September 17, 2025 | Source: Chair Powell's Press Conference Transcript

  • Labour Market: ✗ — "Unemployment rate has edged up, job gains have slowed, and downside risks to employment have risen." "Less dynamic and somewhat softer labor market." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Inflation Concern: 0 — "Inflation has risen recently and remains somewhat elevated." Tariff effects expected to be "short-lived—a one-time shift." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Policy Bias: Easing (+2) — "Decided to lower our policy interest rate by ¼ percentage point." "Appropriate...to take another step toward a more neutral policy stance." "Most judged...appropriate to ease policy further." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Risk Asymmetry: ✓ — "Downside risks to employment having increased, the balance of risks has shifted." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ — One participant voted against, preferring a ½ point cut; a few preferred no change. "Wide dispersion of views" in SEP dot plot. [Source: press_monetary_policy]

TONE: DOVISH — The rate cut is justified by rising employment risks and a shift toward a more neutral policy stance, despite elevated inflation viewed as temporary. Clear signals for potential further easing were given, alongside acknowledged internal divergence.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: September 17, 2025 | Source: SEP

  • Labour Market: 0 — Median unemployment rate projected at 4.5% for 2025, gradually declining to 4.2% by 2028. [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ — Median PCE inflation projected at 3.0% for 2025, then 2.6% (2026), 2.1% (2027), and 2.0% (2028). [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Policy Bias: Easing (+2) — Federal funds rate median projections show a ¼ percentage point lower path for 2025 compared to June, with expectations of further easing. [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Risk Asymmetry: ✓ — Strong tilt towards employment downside risks (16 participants for upside unemployment risk). [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ — Wide dispersion of views in the federal funds rate dot plot for 2025 (ranging 2.5% to 4.75%). [Source: press_monetary_policy]

TONE: DOVISH — The SEP indicates a projected easing of policy with lower federal funds rate path and a clear skew in risks towards higher unemployment (downside for employment), despite inflation remaining above target for 2025.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: September 17, 2025 | Source: FOMC Statement

  • Labour Market: ✗ — "Job gains have slowed, and the unemployment rate has edged up but remains low." Revised language from "solid" to reflect softening. [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Inflation Concern: ✗ — "Inflation has moved up and remains somewhat elevated." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Policy Bias: Easing (+2) — "Decided to lower the target range for the federal funds rate by 1/4 percentage point to 4 to 4-1/4 percent." Justified by "shift in the balance of risks." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Risk Asymmetry: ✓ — "Judges that downside risks to employment have risen." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ — "Voting against this action was Stephen I. Miran, who preferred to lower the target range for the federal funds rate by 1/2 percentage point." [Source: press_monetary_policy]

TONE: DOVISH — A rate cut was implemented due to increasing downside risks to employment and a softening labor market, despite inflation remaining elevated, indicating a shift towards supporting employment.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: September 16-17, 2025 | Source: FOMC Minutes

  • Labour Market: ✗ — "Labor market conditions had softened." "Unemployment rate edged up." "Job gains were revised down notably." "Downside risks to employment...tilted to the downside." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Inflation Concern: ✗ — "Consumer price inflation remained somewhat elevated." "PCE price index...2.7 percent," "Core PCE price inflation...2.9 percent." "Upside risks to their outlooks for inflation." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Policy Bias: Easing (+2) — "Almost all members agreed to lower the target range for the federal funds rate 1/4 percentage point." "Most judged that it likely would be appropriate to ease policy further over the remainder of this year." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Risk Asymmetry: 0 — "Downside risks to employment...increased," and "risks around the inflation forecast as skewed to the upside." "Importance of taking a balanced approach." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ — "One member voted against that decision, preferring to lower the target range 1/2 percentage point." [Source: press_monetary_policy]

TONE: NEUTRAL — The minutes reveal a consensus for a rate cut due to softening labor market and rising employment risks, balanced by elevated inflation and persistent upside risks. A stated commitment to further easing, alongside notable dissent, points to ongoing policy debate.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: August 22, 2025 | Source: Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy

  • Labour Market: 0 — Reaffirms commitment to "maximum employment," noting it's "not directly measurable" and assessments are uncertain. [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Inflation Concern: 0 — Reaffirms "price stability" and "inflation at the rate of 2 percent" as the longer-run goal. [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Policy Bias: Data-dependent (0) — Emphasizes a "balanced approach" when objectives conflict, considering "extent of departures" and "different time horizons." [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Risk Asymmetry: 0 — Mentions "assessments of the balance of risks, including risks to the financial system." (General statement). [Source: press_monetary_policy]
  • Internal Divergence: ✗ — Not applicable to a foundational policy statement.

TONE: NEUTRAL — A reaffirmation of the dual mandate and the 2% inflation target, outlining the long-term policy framework without immediate directional signals.

Self-Healing

  • RSS Documents Needed:
    • Minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee, July 29–30, 2025 — Source: This would provide critical context for the "shift in the balance of risks" cited in September's communications.
    • Federal Reserve issues FOMC statement, July 30, 2025 — Source: The July statement is necessary to fully track the evolution of the FOMC's policy language and initial risk assessments before the September cuts.
    • Federal Open Market Committee announces its tentative meeting schedule for 2027, September 05, 2025 — Source: While not a policy document, it indicates the forward-looking operational aspects of the Fed.
  • High-Value Inputs to Add:
    • **Complete SEP Tables:** Provide all tables and figures from the SEP documents, especially the diffusion indexes for uncertainty and risks for all periods, to allow for more precise scoring.
    • **Full Transcripts for Press Conferences:** Ensure all pages of press conference transcripts are OCR'd and provided, as snippets might miss nuances or specific questions.
  • Weaknesses in Provided Inputs:
    • **Missing July 2025 FOMC Statement/Minutes:** Crucial historical policy context is missing for initial rate decisions; provide OCR or text for these.
    • **Inconsistent SEP Data:** The provided December SEP is an accessible version and does not contain the detailed risk asymmetry diffusion indexes present in the September SEP; provide consistent SEP formats.

Max 6 bullets across all sections. Be precise, directive, and avoid filler.
